text: We'll hear arguments next in 5176, Franks against Delaware.
Thank you.
But is there nothing, a related question that flows from that, if there's enough in the warrant which is true to support the search?
Yes, that's true.

Mr. Huntley, I've read the colloquy between Judge Bush and trial counsel in the Delaware trial court and I gather what his -- what the trial counsel sought to contest was the affiance representation as to what had been told him by two other people, is that correct?
Not entirely, Your Honor.
Well, what -- and in what respect does that incorrect?
The contested allegations in the search warrant affidavit were very simply whether certain conversations took place at all.
And he wanted to show that they had not had any conversations with the affiant and the affiant had said they had?
Exactly.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the court.
But it -- it certainly indicated that the anticipative putting on the testimony of informers who would deny that they had any conversations like that at all?
When you say informer sir, they were named witnesses.
Yes.
That's he wanted to do, Your Honor.
But what if he had a -- what if he had prepared an informal offer of proof to which was attached affidavits of the witnesses?
That's a different proposition, Your Honor.
Well, why would that be different in terms of the fourth corners rule?
Well, Rule 41(c) of the Delaware Criminal Rules specifies on supression of evidence that the motion will be by affidavit -- supported by affidavit, I should say, and specifies all this.

But would you -- would you say that it's a -- would you say that if he hadn't made a formal offer of proof supported by affidavits by -- of the witnesses who say, “We never had any conversation with the officer, whatsoever?”
If he had shown --
And then that -- then let's suppose the Delaware Court had still said “It doesn't make any difference what your submission is.
No.
Constitutionally wrong?
Constitutional --
Well, that's what the issue is here.
I would say it's not constitutionally wrong, unless the court considers the -- and the only out would be judicial integrity, it would appear to me in that case.
Well, you would still say that Delaware constitutionally could say “We're going to -- we're just not going to allow any kind of an attack on the -- on the warrant.”
Yes, Your Honor.
Certainly, that's what the Supreme Court Delaware said.
Now, when we come --
Well, didn't -- didn't the Supreme Court of Delaware take that position?
I'd just like to --
Rugendorf?
I would merely like to take issue with Colonel Turner's characterization of the present question as an extension of the exclusionary rule.
Well, thank you gentlemen.
